The bizarre slew of opinions of regarding this wildly popular show has always fascinated me. From those who praise the show for a simplistic but well-cast plethora of characters from all walks of life, to those who will write it off as a moeblob, and even those who perceive it to be inferior to its much more popular counterpart, The iDOLM@STER, it's just odd to see that even those who adore this graceful work of art don't attempt to unravel what Sakurako Kimino is trying to say.
To be blunt, these interpretations completely miss the point of this show, though I can't fault anyone for doingso, as this is marketed in a way that is seemingly misses its niche, which I'll explain later. At its very core Love Live! School Idol Project is a psychological study on the precepts of emotionalism versus rationalism, an exploration of what causes the barrier of pseudo-intellectual mindset to shatter upon nearing adolescence, a critique on the reality TV fetish in first world countries, a scathing indictment on the argumentative comfort of laurel-based rhetoric, an analysis on the lack of inherent value in the exonerative blame-game played amongst acquaintances, a thought-provoking work that questions what it means to be a leader, a marvelously-crafted excursion into the process of self-denial, and most of all: a commentary on how a unanimous goal brings people together, and what happens when they become too defined by their faith. And that's not even a complete list. 


Before I divulge into my analysis of this show's staggering tapestry of themes, I have to do away with some of my personal preconceptions of what I was to take of this show. If you don't want to hear my previously unfounded stance on the idol obsession, skip the next paragraph.


Before I viewed this show, I had thought that idol-based anime were of a breed inferior to even harems. The very idea that there's only girls running around a school, and that a striking number of Western anime fans, particularly the male ones, indulge in viewership of it, struck me as a more deplorable genre than harems. Because in harems, self-insertion is the key (unless it’s Heaven’s Lost Property, Tomoki is too damn hilarious to be reduced to an audience stand-in,) and with that, it to an extent, requires its audience to at least have a modicum of fantasizing and thought. However, with female-centric shows like this, the characters might just be too simple for girls to relate to, and for guys to fawn over for the said simplicity. It doesn’t require any kind of thought from the audience whatsoever, which turned me off the the genre itself. If I had to be honest, I only watched this because of the meteoric ascent of fan-favorite girl Niko Yazawa. I thought it was gonna be about cute girls and that Nico would just be a fun character. And boy was I proven wrong. Although on the surface, the show does everything you expect it to, there is so much more going on beyond it. 


And without further ado, let's get right into the review!


On paper, the story works, and is as effective as it is simplistic. But you'd be hard-pressed to find an idea that doesn't work on paper, as the entire premise of outlining the gist of the story is to be synoptic and evaluate the principle, first, and the execution residing in its translation into audiovisual media. An example of failure in translation is the case of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s unparalled classic novel, The Great Gatsby, which offers one of America’s most beloved stories, yet is always rightfully panned in cinema form. Conversely, the case of Love Live! School Idol Project, falls nothing short of what it proposes.


Unlike other shows of it's nature, Love Live is completely punctual with what it's overarching goal is. From the very first episode, there is as much intrigue as there is a straightforward execution. In comparison to K-On, for example, where Yui at first very vaguely seeks to join a club and just happens to stumble on the Light Music Club, Love Live! has our heroine, Honoka, preparing to shoot the moon from the start. Her school is on the decline due to a lack of enrollment, and she's ill-prepared to transfer, given her lack of study and academic aptitude. One could argue that K-On prides itself in subtlety (most likely Digibro,) whereas Love Live! spells out its fiery ambition from the start, and ironically, the latter argument would be the one that doesn't delve into the deeper implications.


Where the introduction truly distinguishes itself, is the fact that Honoka has to convince herself that she loves the school. Her and her compatriots, Umi and Kotori travel the school, finding tons of reasons why she has to stay and bring more people there. But there’s the catch, she doesn’t know why, she’s just inept as a student. This self-induced delusion is a very human thing to do, and already sets the show off on good footing aside from the rest of what is on display. 


From there on out, the show follows a general pattern, they have a quick obstacle, then they get new members really fast, move forward, and are rarely impeded in their ascent until Honoka’s illness. The other idol groups are rarely presented, as this is a character-centric narrative, similar to how Steins;Gate never really showed much of SERN or the future failure would entail (although that show is hindered in hindsight of that, because it's the opposite case.) One of the main criticisms of the show is that characters are elided into the group all too quickly, and aren’t explored with proper depth. But this couldn’t be further from the truth, as I’ll explain with the character section below.


For the sake of the characters, I’ll be delving into the more favorited trio, and only quickly describe in a more general stroke, as this section will be relatively lengthy. 


Honoka is defined more by her false atavism and reverence for the school. As I said before, her initial intrigue stems from the fact that she doesn’t even know why she venerates the school. She’s proceeds to ask her friends about what’s good, what can lure people into the school in the first episode, providing implications into why she . Her naive yet cheerful attitude does so much to boost the entertainment value of the show, so much that you won’t even realize that she is going too far, that her subtle selfishness is pre-meditated throughout the whole show. All the girls in the show rally around her ebullience and persistence to save their school. Her drive and optimism on their own make fans who enjoy her character smile and be easily coalesced into the very essence that makes her a protagonist, while her detractors will be overwrought with an unending smugness over the very failures that stem from it, prime example being when she went unconscious during a live performance on the school rooftop, due to the fact that she was exercising in the rain, during the wee hours of the morning, thus leaving her in a horrible condition. Her selfishness upon discovering that Kotori has to leave stems from this in a way that went over everyone’s head: she had come this far, and her stupidity synthesizing with the arrogance that the faith that everyone bestows upon her, is a clear-cut reason for her otherwise irrational actions towards her. This event explores the pitfalls of faith, from her holding it toward her goal, as well as that of others placing it in her. But our protagonist is nothing in face of the real best girl, Umi.


Umi Sodona is undoubtedly one of the most ingenious characters ever conceived. Most would misconstrue her thematic presence to write her off as pandering material due to her innate introversion, and it's not difficult to veer into as to why. The skeptical rhetoric she displays from the very beginning is a piece most idol fans will appreciate, and that coupled with her shyness and loyalty make for a well-rounded character for this type of show (traits of which I'll return to shortly.) But this is merely grazing the surface, one that does not represent the bigger picture any more than smugly proclaiming that George Orwell's 1984 is of no more value than a scathing indictment of the Soviet Union relative to its publication. The beloved Umi-chan is Sakurako Kimino's proxy in traversing the primordial Apollonian and Dionysian conflict. The temporality of contemporary society is no doubt the launchpad for her writing. From the very inception of Honoka's practically zealous proposition, Umi held it to scrutiny. Being faced with her childhood friend of all people, she gradually refrains from using her abundant rationale, as Kotori helps convinces her to stand with her friend's selfish desires via the fallacy of relative privation. Kotori argues that based on a lack of regrets as younger children underneath her wing, Umi should refrain from being so skeptical. Her concise yet thought-provoking loss of thought is similar to that of A Clockwork Orange. In that story, protagonist Alex chooses to submit his right to choose, but does it out of seeing it as an easy way out of prison. Umi, does it because of the faith-based delusions of her friends, the influence that causes internal ambivalence towards the idea, but never the people around her. But that already explains itself, those she's surrounded by, tug her away from the Apollonian, and into the Dionysian. This reinforces the theme of Apollonian self-denial that Maki and Eri also go through, whereas Niko has the same process through the emotional pattern, and that Nozomi, Rin, and Hanayo experience. The reassurance of lifelong friends, and their laurels is a subtle jab at western feminist culture in itself, given how one of their borderline dogmatic contentions is that any woman who opposes their cause is thriving off the achievement of the movement's past, and therefore should not be in opposition to it. And everything about this message is handled with profound subtlety and class, which is also the very crux that makes Umi a human character, despite having such an undertaking to deliver so many messages in the span of 13 episodes.  


What makes this girl in particular stand out from her eight friends and peers, is that her mannerisms are portrayed in such a unique foil to her peers. She's shy, but nowhere near as much as Nanayo upon her introduction. She begins practical, but doesn't use it as an excuse to be as tsunderiffic as Maki's reluctance to join the group. She's got the qualities of a leader, but nowhere near the cocksure attitude of Nico. I could go on, but you get the picture. The one thing that she has that is shown in a truly humanistic portrayal is that of her insecurity. Whereas Eri blares over her insecurity with a collected attitude and infodumps her characterization to the audience, Umi goes around discussing matters in a way that implicates it, slowly allowing any categorization by way of the term, “dandere,” to exfoliate, and for the density of the script to show in all its glory. Her argument with Eri, during the same episode where her ballet past is revealed, is one of the most erroneously scripted pieces of dialogue I have heard. It's unfashionably easy to pick apart the flaws in both their mindsets. Umi shouldn't take to heart what someone thinks of a genre as a whole, but you can't blame her if you understand the prowess of her psychological shifts. It's a humanistic portrayal of how she's rising to her goal but losing her critical mindset at the same time. It's a beautiful moment in the series, one that goes massively overlooked. As the degradation of Umi's rhetoric spirals downward into cognitive biases and emotional decisions, her intellect is used sparingly on her friends as a reminder to is who she is. And this is the beauty of her character. The few strands of who she once was is still explored, from her lecture to Honoka on why what she did to Kotori was overdone, as well as using her athletic skills to coordinate drills for the girls. And yes, she is very cute, and is now on my sodomy list. Overall, Umi is quite the profound character, and a robust take on the dandere archetype that I won't soon forget.


Niko Yazawa is a postmodern critique of the pseudo-intellectual sphere of the Internet. Every facet of her character can, and should be compared to that of users who squabble over opinions by projection and escapism that deludes one into convincing themselves that they are intellectually superior to others. Upon her arrival quite early into the show, she dons a rather tacked-on disguise,  and projects her personality as more credible by chiding every single chink in Honoka's ignorance. Niko's vitriol is furthered as she is seen commenting on the µs' first music video, stating that they are "ten years too early to claim they're idols!" She complements her rage-induced diatribe with the use of an emoticon, which is a clear allegory to the nature of forum users who will subconsciously allocate all their mental capacity to their eloquence, in order to simultaneously project themselves as the superior position without truly articulating any tangible points in their contrarian "polemic." Given the meteoric ascent of atheism, the alt-right, and other ideological frameworks (or lack thereof, to give the former at least some credit) due to the impression they can leave on unironically contrarian high school students, it’s easy to assume that Kimino sought to take a reactionary stance to ironically, the neo-reactionaries. 


Never before has a moe (Lain doesn’t count) character ever been used as an allegory to the contemporary state of the Internet, tackle the issue of projection with depth, as well as serve as the show’s memetic magnet, done in a practicable manner, and possibly never before if my memory serves me right.  Her slyly satiric portrayal of basement-dwelling projection is discomforting to audiences who aren’t fawning over her inherent cuteness, but her alter ego(s) make her literally three-dimensional in nature. She runs around ruining µ’s practices, stealing food, disguising herself, hid her idol obsession, and fuels an alternative persona to compensate for the ugly nature she harbors. As we all know, she’s self-centered and egotistical, but over time she becomes more and more acquainted with the group, but doesn’t really do so, and stays humorous. The crux of this, is her controversial catchphrase, “Nico nico nii~.” Some say it’s just fanboy bait, while she’s actually still a stuck-up bitch. I forward the proposition: Why does her being the latter make her a bad character? How boring would the group be if everyone was super nice? This show is supposed to layer humor and exuberance over the true nature of humanity, like Boogie Nights before it (although it was more straightforward, being that it is a film that had to make a statement.) Her projection as an alternative persona, a lovable little girl that all idol fans will love, and relying her knowledge to move up is showing us in the endless pursuit of opportunism, that all the well fails without moving with her group, as her moment of overthinking, and letting her hair down for the camera showed.


This mental dichotomy is further accentuated when factoring in the story behind her cultivated persona. For those of you that don’t know, there’s an anecdote her character has outside of the show that explains the affably lovable mantra, “Nico nico nii!” I’d advise all fans to read it if they haven’t already, but for those who won’t, the story boils down to her dad always doing it (purported to be affirmed in season 2 when her family is explored, but I haven’t seen it yet.) This backstory adds yet another dimension to her already complex character. 


Nozomi serves as a symbolic proxy of arguing how one can live happily in a predestined life, and serves as one who can be compared to ironically the unpredictable characters like Netero from Hunter x Hunter. The paradox of her character is to serve as a comedic relief character that simultaneously serves as manna for the severely misinterpreted doctrine of Calvinism. Calvinists and their subsidiaries, the Puritans offered pessimistic viewpoints often construed as pointless. Why live your life in any way if you’re cynical of the world due to Puritan promotion of education, and you tote the belief that the end result of your life shall not change regardless of your actions? Nozomi consults her Tarot cards, which can be interpreted as a response to Tumblr’s obsession with zodiac signs, but since she doesn’t try to compartmentalize people in any way besides their breast size, I’ll side with the notion that it’s the aforementioned case regarding history’s indifference to the truth behind predestination. She has fun, she spends lots of time with Eri, and has her moment of chronicling the lives of the members before they even attain a modicum of attention, and shatters any neutrality one might have against her with her comedic flavor of always fondling the breasts of her fellow idols. It’s quite simple what to do when your lifestyle promotes pessimism as much as it promotes fates set in stone, you accept what you know has been destined, as Nozomi does when she checks her cards with a smile on her face. The way even the most pessimistic of intellectuals stayed alive is too keep pursuing knowledge, or sharing it with people. The role Nozomi plays in the narrative is similar to that of Jim Casy from The Grapes of Wrath. As for the the aforementioned chronicling, that episode made quite a devastating comment on the duplicitous nature of reality TV shows. No one in Keeping Up With The Kardashians talks about Kim’s sumptuous encounters and releases with Ray J, just like no one recorded talks about how Nico has a secret idol backlog that no one in the entire school knew about. Seeing this from the perspective of high school students is harrowing. 


The rest are easier to pin down, Maki is a tsundere that adds to Nico as well as serves as an interesting take on composition that makes modern audiences swoon over older styles of music, Eli is the only failure, as the abstract representations of her childhood were incomprehensible, then she literally delivered on exposition on her personality on Honoka that rendered the flashbacks useless, and were heavily-handed. Rin is underrated because she doesn’t actually say “nya” to an annoying extent, and her childhood dilemma about being berated for trying to be feminine is supposed to evoke empathy from men who have the same issue, not women. Kotori represents the obscene conflict high school students have to undergo, constantly rethinking if she wants to pursue education, or her job, the latter being her practice in the end, as well as showing that the innate nervousness of breaking news to our friends no matter how many times we swear to do it, will always take a toll on us. 


The presentation of this story is crafted so meticulously. Classic films like The Searchers and Taxi Driver give a view of the inside looking out at the world, Leo Tolstoy's sprawling magnum opus War and Peace shows the outside looking in at his gallery of characters. Love Live! accentuates its differences, as showing the dead center, looking around. Every vicissitude is expounded on greatly, as the directors consistently draw upon as much faith as the idols have to their success, only to masterfully dramatize every vicissitude relative to their predicaments. It's evocative of the way the Monogatari series is presented: everything focused upon during the screentime is given detail. Every new character that they stumble on is shown in more detail than a few background junkies dispersed throughout the screen. This is why Honoka always runs into the same three girls who support the idol club. This is why you only see women in the show. It's all a matter of perspective, and it wastes no time on developing the otaku haven, the municipality of Akibahara. Takahiko Kyogoku familiarizes you with the students, by allowing you a claustrophobic detail a la Martin Scorsese's 1973 film Mean Streets, without the perspective of New York, but with all the grandeur of their performances that project to the world.


The art, is one of the most subtle paradoxes the ever exist in this medium. Though the world is bleak, the vibrant, albeit generic color palette shines, with quite the self-awareness of its concomitant duplicity. It will deceive you greatly, but this is nary a facet of this show's presentation that doesn't serve a grander purpose. Juxtaposing well-drawn anime girls to allure a non-critical audience with a staggering amount of criticism, many exuding too much profundity and erudition for the people it criticizes to notice, is an underappreciated aspect of the story. The vibrant colors are aren’t slathered over, it’s all innocuous so that it becomes a subdued experience thematically, and hilariously dramatized in other departments.


The best part of the artistic flair is that of its camera angles. The impeccable usage of varying shots all give the girls a larger-than-life feel. The best way to describe this, is how much it resembles Stanley Kubrick's underrated triumph, Paths of Glory. As Kirk Douglas was portrayed with lower camera angles during his major monologues in the court case in the aforementioned film, every character is mostly portrayed from a lower or up-front angle in a similar matter. Every character exudes an aura of charisma, and evoke a larger-than-life feel that is worked in equal parts the impeccable script as it is by the marvelous camerawork. This method of looking up towards the characters makes them seem as big as they fall, as your perception is shattered time and time again, when our heroines are shown through the bleakest of times, from performing to an empty audience, to Honoka's illness taking a toll on her consciousness. The minute they are looked down upon, you feel the levity they do, due to the immaculate presentation. The abject horror Yukihiro Wantanabe, and Miho Sugiura can instill from every idol member and even the viewer is astounding in every sense of the word. 


Another distinctive trait is the sparing yet effective usage of shaky cam. Expanding on aforementioned the "harder-they-fall" concept, a prime example of the dramatic camera ruptures is found upon the first time Eri trains the girls using ballet means, as it is effective in flexibility. As they all flail and struggle against their burning muscles, and the escalation of difficulty in their training regiments, Youhei Sasaki frames the scene at a skewed angle, slanted from below, and with a constant shaky movement of the camera. The swift animation of the idols fighting for the top spot is amplified by the way the scene is dramatized. The shaky effect makes it all that much more intense building up to the resounding failures, whether it be Honoka's rooftop collapse, or the aforementioned scene, wherein Rin is the first to collapse in her ballet stance. It's all-in-all a fantastic trick, grounded by fluid motion and not overdone in a nauseating velocity. 


My only true complaint about this misinterpreted masterpiece is the abysmal CGI, something I think most of us can agree on. It’s usage in the opening and performances stilts the transitions and runs at a slower framerate than the hand-drawn animation. 


As for something one would usually think would be a selling point of this show, the music, to put it simply, is stale outside a few hit-or-miss songs like Start;Dash. The actual intro is different, as it’s not the template that offers a few random shots of characters, rather it’s just one overdone CGI crapfest. In my opinion, the actual song used would be better used as a next episode preview, rather than a way to open the show. Regardless, some people will like it, and others won’t. Just know what you’re getting into as the most important songs are going to be pop-oriented, and is only complemented by a generic soundtrack that does little but appropriate the mood of any given scene. If you abhor pop music in any matter, it shouldn’t deter you too much as they are only brief respites from the messages in each episode, and aren’t too insulting to those who consider their taste above generic pop. 


Lastly, the conclusive note I'll instill into the few who have trudged through this merely synoptic overlook of this piece's dizzying social insights, is not that of a summative note. Rather, I'll go off on a tangent for what this means for the foreseeable future of this community. The severe misinterpretation of this show's meaning, is done in by those who came in expecting a simple idol story, or even a moe shitfest that will be burned at the stake by people such as fans of ThatAnimeSnob. Oddly enough, it takes a ridiculously open mind from a fan of meanings that are by no means promiscuous. It masquerades itself as a simple moeblob, something people who want simple, light-hearted entertainment about cute girls will seek after. It scares away those who spend all their time perpetuating their critical mindset in search of the most thought-provoking anime for the same reason. It’s almost as if it’s meant to be considered a diamond not in the rough, but hidden in plain sight. 


I guess the point I’m trying to make here, is that people watched this for the wrong reasons. The beliefs they held about what this show is going to be are, in fact met at the most fundamental level. And like I said, it’s not a misrepresentation that is uncommon around here. They will praise it for the reasons it’s supposed to be praised, and the supposed intellectuals of MAL won’t get around to scrape up the deeper meanings. It is an argument often made that those who are too critical aren’t any better if they cling to certain genres, and hinge their enjoyment on intellectual fulfillment, but obscured themes in shows like these show that they aren’t mutually exclusive, and that clinging to genre conventions and stakes is no way to interpret a show. 


The best way to describe this show is that of a horny NEET that desperately craves for sex, but doesn't do anything provocative, and dresses themselves in plain garments. It only does things that attract a comfortable image, in a way where they're almost scared to say what they think, and hide it behind a comforting exterior. It's just that the people who are just as horny won’t even look their way, because they won’t find appeal as easily in. 


In that case, the show is almost too subtle for its own good, in a way where I can't even call it avant-garde in nature. All I can hope is that this panegyric will do something to rectify that. 


Thanks for reading, NICO NICO NII LOVES YOU!

At first, I'm not that kind of guy who watches anime series about Japanese idols because my preferred anime genres are action, science fiction, fantasy, superpower, comedy and slice-of-life. When I've first tried to watch the first episode of Love Live!, everything changed and it is now of my favorite series. Well then, let's get to the review rundown of the series.
Story - Otonokizaka High School is in trouble of closing down because the number of students enrolling this school is dropping lower and lower every year, the school will totally shut down after its first years graduated. Honoka Kousaka, a second year of studentof the said school, doesn't want her school to shut down for good. When she goes to the popular UTX High School in order to find solutions for the prevention of closing down, she watches the performance of A-Rise, a school idol group in UTX, because of this she was inspired to start up an idol group of her own. With the help of Kotori Minami and Umi Sonoda, her childhood friends, they formed the idol group called μ's (Muse), named after the nine Greek goddesses of music, in order to boost popularity to her school. However, it is not an easy task because Eli Ayase, the student council president, opposes the idea of creating a school idol and she'll do anything using her own power to prevent the shut down of her school. In order to make things worse, Honoka and her friends are getting issues of recruiting new members. But when they heard about the idol competition called Love Live!, they'll able to get attention to win and promote the school. Because of this, Honoka is determined to win in order to prevent the school from total closure. The series story and plot is perfect because it shows determination of the characters.


Music and Sound - As expected, the series music and sound are awesome especially the series' opening music, "Bokura wa Ima no Naka de" and "Start: Dash", one of μ's insert song performances. All of the lyrics are relatable because some words of the lyrics gives motivation to the viewers that's why I've enjoyed it.


Characters - All of the members of μ's are very cute and sweet. They've different personalities as well like Honoka is very energetic and determined, Kotori (my waifu)  is cute and sweet girl, Umi is polite and friendly, Maki is a tsundere, etc. 


Voice Acting - In the original Japanese version, all of the members of μ's made noise in Japan and the whole wide world because of their awesome music and PVs (Promotional Videos). Their voice acting is very good and they were able to express their emotions very well. In the English dubbed version of the series, I've realized most of the voice actresses, such as Kira Buckland (Kuroyukihime of Accel World), Erica Mendez (Ryuko Matoi of Kill La Kill), Xanthe Huynh (Yuna Yuki of Yuki Yuna is a Hero), Laura Post (Ragyo Kiryuin of Kill La Kill) and Caitlin Glass (Winry Rockbell of Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood) are strong fanatics of Love Live. Plus, they bring a television actress, Marieve Herington, who also had a role of a TV sitcom "How I Met Your Mother?", to provide the English speaking voice of Honoka and former competitive gamer, Faye Mata. Likewise, they were able to deliver their voice very well.


Animation and Art - The series is animated by Sunrise, an animation studio that brings you Gundam franchise (suprised? because the studio is notable for action, mecha series), gives the realistic art of some locations in Akihabara such as the Kanda Shrine which became popular thanks to the series. The CGI animation of Sunrise is superb because it gives viewers the feeling of watching PVs.


Enjoyment - The series is super awesome to watch because of the great music and animation. Not only that, the funny scenes will give you laughter when you're down. I've even tried to download one of their songs to my computer and android phone.

Love Live! School Idol Project is probably one of my favorite anime to date. It's cute, funny, fun to watch, and the songs are fun to dance and sing along to! 
Story: 10/10
The story basically goes like this; 9 girls get together when they learn that their school is shutting down to form a school idol group named Muse. With all of them working together they hope to make it to the school idol competition Love Live!
I found this story to be outstanding, it was fun to watch and it always kept my attention throughout the anime.
Art: 8/10
This is my least favorite part of theanime, though the art is great, the 3D animation throughout the songs is odd and not the best looking, it really stood out but it is a creative idea, but it is the reason I'm giving this an 8. Besides that, the art is cute and they do a great job with the animation minus the 3D, which they improved on in the end.\n\n
Sound: 10/10\n
The OST is great throughout the 2 seasons, and the songs they sing throughout they really can get to you with the girls' beautiful singing voices mixed with the music, I think it's absolutely outstanding.\n\n
Characters: 9/10\n
These girls are colorful, fun, and very energetic! Most are very original and you feel a strong connection with each girl as you learn more about them, and you will at least love one of these girls to death by the end of this idol journey! The only girl I had a problem with was Nico Yazawa, but that's definitely a strong personal opinion since I know tons of fans who love her. Their voices fit with the designs and the outfits were absolutely beautiful, making the girls shine throughout their performances and making me want to cosplay them even more and waste money on them.\n\n
Enjoyment: 10/10\n
Even though this anime has some flaws, I enjoyed all the seasons and even the movie a whole lot, and the spin-off has got me hooked with the new girls. This really got me into music and into idol anime. I never thought I would love this stuff so much.\n\n
Overall: 9/10\n
This anime is great! It really makes you happy when you're upset and you'll feel like these characters are your friends and they are all really likable, the music is fun to sing along to as well! I recommend this to everyone reading this, and I also recommend afterwards watching the outstanding movie and the spin-off series, Love Live! Sunshine!! \n\n
Thank you for reading my review on Love Live! School Idol Project, I hope this helps!

I'd consider it the Star Wars of idol anime. There's nothing unique or interesting about it, I've seen shows that have done everything I seen in Love Live and the plot is kinda contrived and generic.  I've heard that in Japan there are designated spots where you can literally kneel and worship the members of U's like actual religious figures, and I'm like "are people really that obsessed with these characters?". 
However, it does a really great job at what it does. Now, I want to put this out of the way and say that while I like the content of idol shows, Idon't like the actual music in them about 70% of the time. I loved the emotional aspect of the show, I wanted to see Honoka and her friends succeed and the show does a great job at showing how much hard work it is to throw together a bunch of random girls in a school and turn them into national celebrities. There's only a couple things I don't agree with as far as the plot goes, and that's that the reuniting of Honoka and Kotori didn't end with a kiss, and the entire existence of Nico. At least I can go to doujins for that.\n
Love Live, at least in every other anime community I've ever been in, is incredibly popular and I feel my review of it is barely justified unless there's about 5 people who are still on the fence about it. I hated it for years without even giving it a shot, but when I did, I thought it was better than average. Not something I'd personally look back on, but there's a lot of fans of the series who swear by it to death. Give it a shot if you got nothing else to do, it'll either eat up an afternoon or change your life.

When I was an early teen, I was very much obsessed with girl band groups, ever since I watched K-On~ And this show reminds me very much of it. It brings back good memories.
My first exposure to this anime wasn't the anime, itself, but the smart-phone music-rhythm game, "School Idol," associated with this. I downloaded it about 4 months ago. I knew the game was based of this anime series, but I was reluctant to finally watch this, because I felt it would ruin the game's immersion for me. 
But I'm really glad that I did finally decide to watch this! 
The plot and charactersare so cute! I love the little flashbacks.


I quickly loved the plot. It actually adds drama to series, but it's not a brilliantly big problem, but there is at least some conflict. I felt the plot took too long to develop in the beginning. And at the end, it got really sped up. 

The art is overall really good, but something that bugs me is that during the dance scenes it seems as if the animators were indecisive (or lazy???) and kept on switching from 3-D figures to 2-D drawings, vice versa. It kind of threw the choreography and the immersion off. I wish that they would pick one art style... 


However, I do prefer the 2-D dance animation, because it seems more expressive and less robotic compared to the 3-D dance animation.


The characters are a little cliche. It's easy to tell which characters are the air head, the soft spoken one, the tsundere, the shy one, the intelligent one, the cool-acting one, etc.


I do very much enjoy this anime, though. I cried a lot, maybe because I'm sensitive and sentimental! But scenes pulled at my heart strings and made me blubber.

Story: This was the one anime that got me into musical animes. I actually started this series by playing the app on my phone. When I discovered this anime, and when my friend found out that I played the game, I just had to pick this up and join them. The story is pretty simple. A girl named Honoka goes to an all girls high school that's about to be shut down. Not wanting that to happen, she tries to find ways to get girls to come and apply to the school. When she discovers that a rival school has an Idol Group that performsin competitions, she decides to start her own Idol group with her two friends and new girls along the way. It's pretty generic, but I promise that there is more realistic drama in here than what the poster entails. The friendships made in this show are not bullshit. They actually take time to form and there are backstories that make us relate to each of the girls. Out of all the musical animes you could watch, this is a must at 10/10.


Art: The art is just as cutesy and shojo as it gets, but instead of just using 2D animation all the time, they do use some 3D for some song scenes. I do admit that the 3D can be hokey at times, but for some songs, it's pretty good. Because of the colorful atmosphere, it really reminds us that this is a musical anime, and that there's bound to be good music in here. (Where's the iTunes for America!?!??!?!) Because of this, I think 9/10 is in order.


Sound: Since this is a musical anime, music does play a major role. I have to say that a lot of songs from this show are really good. The opening is fantastic. The ending is really good (and creative that each voice actress gets her own solo in each episode, but personally, I like the all together ending). I'm trying to figure out which song inside the anime itself is my favorite because they are all pretty darn good. I think I have a tie between Susume or Bokura no LIVE Kimi to no LIFE. They are pretty fun to sing to. If I do have one complaint, I really don't like Kotori's voice. It's pretty squeaky and she can't even sing in my opinion. Fortunately, she doesn't sing too much, so I'm pretty satisfied with that. Overall, I think I would rate this section a 10 out of 10 as well.


Character: The main girls each have a major role to play in the show. I will warn you that the majority of the girls' personalities are tropes because you need different personalities, ami rite?

Honoka: She is basically your leader and your cute innocent. She's naive, but she's kind and she's determined to do what's right vs. wrong. She loves her friends greatly, and she does get frustrated at times. For a main character, she's pretty good.

Umi: Umi's the nonchalant yet sarcastic best friend of Honoka's who doesn't try to show much emotion but there are circumstances that she needs to snap Honoka back into reality.

Kotori: She is very nice, but she can't sing, so I complain about this a little bit.

Rin: Three words: Cat girl tomboy

Hanayo: The sweetest thing on the face of the earth. Her shyness is so adorable!

Maki: She is the best singer of the group. You can tell that this girl has been singing her whole life because it's just that good!

Eli: She's the bitchy character who tries to stop the Idol group from happening since she's the president of her class. Her backstory will make you tear up a little.

Nozomi: If there is fanservice in this show, it involves this girl.

Nico: Oh my god, I hate this bitch! She's the short, little brat who thinks she knows everything and if it's her fault, she puts the blame on everyone else. I warn you, she's not fun at all for fun-sized.


With that being the case, I would rate this 8/10.


Enjoyment: If you love J-Pop music, this show is definitely for you. I enjoyed each and every episode of it. I laughed, I smiled, I cried all the way. 10/10


Overall: I recommend this anime, and I'm proud to say that this anime has my personal high score of 9/10.

Love Live! is such a beautiful anime. The storyline, the detail, the characters, everything about it.
First, I was hesitant to watch this anime, yet everyone was talking about it. The story starts with Honoka, a second year in High School. One day she gets dreadful news that her school will be closing down, no longer accepting applications. One day, on her way to school, she stops at a school, featuring a School Idol group named A-Rise. The school would receive a ton of applications because of how popular the Idol Group was. Honoka comes up with the idea, for her and her best friends, Kotori,and Umi, to also be School Idols to hopefully keep the school from shutting down. There is many trial and errors in their adventure to become school idols, but they never stop trying!

I really enjoyed this series. I was recommended this by my brother, who said i  might like it after i expressed my enjoyment of group singing, and i have to say, I really enjoyed this series and thank him for his recommendation. A basic summary, to say the least, is that the protagonists school is closing down, and they form a school idol group to try and save it. Now i won't spoil the ending, i'm not that kind of guy, but i do recommend this, unless you do not like music anime, then i suggest you watch a different anime. Now we getinto the things i didn't like about this anime; the story takes a while to start, and the CG animation they use sometimes is a bit off-putting, especially in the intro, however, I eventually got used to it, I'm not sure if you will however. One of the main things i enjoyed was the songs, I really liked them and feel like i can listen to them outside of the anime. However, 3 episodes out of 13 do not have any songs outside of the intro/outro of the episode, while i admit artists do get tired, it might bother some. Overall i enjoyed the animation and the songs, and felt neutral about CG animation and the slow start to the plot.

I never liked japanese idols, even that vocaloid ones... but I started to play the game of Love Live Idol Festival and I just loved the songs so much and the characters that I looked for the game on Internet and found the anime series.
I thought "let´s give it a shot", I was surprised how much I got "addicted" to this 9-students story. RABU RAIBU.
I downloaded the game a long long time ago and got addicted, so finding out there was a promo anime was really exciting for me, though music animes are generally pretty bland and only leave an impression with cute girls. I figured I'd give it a shot and pray it wasn't mediocre. This is where Love Live differs, (though the girls are also very cute) since the show has a LOT more to offer than the standard idol anime.
This review only applies to season 1, as season 2 would get different scores.
Story: 10
Can't bring myself not to love the story. There wasn't really amain story in the game, more like a bunch of little background information, so seeing the girls get together and interact was an incredible experience. The 3 main girls, 2nd years Kotori, Umi, and Honoka, hear that their school is to be shut down due to lack of interest and struggle to save it by forming an idol group. The girls' dedication to saving their school with which they and their families have history was really touching, and their motivation and love for μ's was inspiring. Love Live really shows the characters moving from the very bottom to the top, and ends with a shocking but realistic ending, albeit very sad. Some girls feel untalented or modest, some girls are nonathletic, some girls feel they aren't girly enough for an idol group, and some have personal grudges against idols, but in the end, they all unite to save the school and form a powerful friendship based on this. The story is original and engaging, so it got a 10 in my book.\n
Art: 10\n
The art for Love Live is beautiful. The girls seem to have a sort of emotion in their eyes and all the girls have subtle differences that make them memorable. The colors are bright and the backgrounds are pretty. During performances, many scenes are changed to CG for smoother flow, and though I'm not a fan of CG in anime, I really think Love Live pulled it off, even if it did take a while to get used to. The animation was smooth and the close-ups of the girls were really detailed, showing individual hair strands and lip gloss.\n
Sound: 10\n
What do you expect from a music anime? The OST was absolutely beautiful and all the songs were really catchy, and it was incredible to see my favorite songs from the game performed. Very impressed with the music. As far as voice acting goes, the VA's were very into it and very emotional. It really showed how dramatic teenage girls can be and I really connected with some of the things these girls would say.\n
Character: 8\n
Since there are so many girls in μ's, it was hard to fit all of them in with character development. Season 2 does cover for this, though, and season 2 leaves a whole different impression on its own. μ's isn't complete until half way through the series, so those who take longer to join got more development than others. Some who got little development included Rin, Maki, Nico, and Nozomi, but luckily season 2 does make up for that and gives some incredible filler episodes later. All filler episodes are dedicated to character development and forming a stronger bond between the nine μ's members. Their interactions are very solid and you really get a sense of friendship and a heavy bond between these girls. As for side characters, there are a few reoccurring ones that help the girls of μ's get to the top, and it's cool to see a school anime also develop side characters.\n
Enjoyment: 10\n
Love Live exceeded my expectations. I am very glad I decided to watch it, since it has easily worked its way into my top animes. It has a charm to it that makes you feel all warm and fuzzy at the end of each episode, and its resolution and ability to recover from sad moments makes it lovable on its own. Honestly, I think anyone could watch this anime, because yes there's eye candy with cute girls, but more than that, there's a friendship and bond you don't see often in animes and there's an inspirational love for these girls who love their school so much that they form an idol group to save it. Please do yourself a favor and watch Love Live! School Idol Project

I'm like everyone else, you know. I haven't watched an idol anime before, but after I watched this, I think I might do it again. But let's get onto the review.
Story: The story follows a simple plotline. The school is closing, and 3 students in particular really want it to keep going. Along the way, they gain members, and many small things happen throughout the entire show. In my opinion, the story wasn't much, but that's mainly because idol animes are more about the songs.
Art: The art in Love Live is pretty good, take the awkward 3D transitions sometimes. The sections in the songs wherethe idols are dancing are always nice to look at, but the 3D makes it look a bit choppy. However, seeing as how the anime is a few years old, I'll let it slide for now. 


Sound: Well, the main focus of any idol anime is the music, right? Love Live delivers that nicely, with lots of the songs being obviously well made and have had time put into them. The opening is catchy and upbeat, and their first concert showcases the trio very well. Also, it's the first idol group where all of them equally are important, so that's pretty cool.


Character: The contrast between the different characters works well with the anime. You can tell what roles that they would fill, and what their position is within the songs that they sing. However, development for the characters is only given to a few of them, so don't expect drastic changes in character from all of them.


Enjoyment: Well, to wrap up this review, I'm going to talk about how enjoyable this was. For me, I enjoyed Love Live more than some people would, seeing as how I appreciate music since I'm "musically inclined" compared to other people. if you like music, and can live without a detailed and long plot, then I think you'd appreciate Love Live. However, if you're into more of the plot-oriented animes, you should probably stay away from animes like Love Live.

I give NAME a 7/10 
(May contain minor spoilers) Do you have what it takes to be a school Idol? What is your purpose in doing so? Do you you wish to pursue stardom? or is there another motive towards your goal? School Idol project shows us the the foundation steps of what it's like to become a school Idol.
This anime in not mediocre as some may say it is, but it's not a masterpiece either. This anime has its flaws but also has its strong points in which it makes itstandout.


Story:

The story follows three aspiring girls in a mission to save their high school from closing down. These three girls have came up with an solution to save their school and that is to form a school Idol club together as they're the most trendiest thing in Japan right now. They will use this idea in hope to bring a new wave of students who then will hopefully apply to this high school which will then prevent it from closing down. Along the way, they find new talents within their own high school which extenders their talent range, from great dancers to great singers.


The story itself is another "Oh I must do THIS to prevent THIS from happening" and after a while I was contemplating if I should continue on to season 2 or just leave off after season 1 ends. Surprisingly enough, the story isn't half bad. The two main focus of this entire story is that it is essentially a MUSIC genred anime with SLICE OF LIFE. Some may argue that Drama is also a part of this story but I disagree as the anime portrays a happy mood all throughout the anime, even when times go tough. I wasn't dissapointed with the story, infact I found it rather enjoyable. 


Art:

The art in this anime reminded me a lot of Shigatsu wa Kimi no Uso which is a compliment as both animes are music. Back to the topic of Love live, the art was really mind blowing at times. We had scenes where the characters were portrayed beautifully with the surroundings which made them standout a lot. The character design was very well done as well as the scenery for the school. 


Apart from the compliments that I'm giving for the art style, there was sometimes really random and unprofessional looking CGI scenes. That made the score the art drop by A LOT. If a show has a great art style that shows scenes with amazement, then it should stay consistent instead of doing a lazy CGI to cover up the 'hard' scenes like the dances.


Sound:

It's a music anime, so you should expect the music to sound good otherwise it just defeats its whole purpose. The music was decent, it wasn't something to be amazed by. After all, some may like it more than I would. Don't get me wrong, I loved some of the songs that were shown in Love Live, and some of the OST's as well. It didn't really create the immersion of pop which is what it's supposed to do. But it didn't give a song that I could be attached to. Even after finishing the anime. 


Character:

The strongest point of this anime is the characters. Each character has their own unique traits and personalities which makes them stand out. I really loved this show for the characters they showed as I liked them all. I especially like the characters such as Umi, Niko, Maki, Eri and Hanayo. Some may liked the others more than I did but hey, didn't I say I liked all the characters? This anime is a prime example of how characters should be portrayed. Instead of having same recycled looking characters, have different characters with different personalities. That is what makes a show stand out.


Enjoyment:

I can say I'm somewhat satisfied with this anime. I could have enjoyed it much more than I thought I could but it definitely beat my expectations. I'm usually not the type to watch anime's with strictly 'girls' protagonists only but this anime took me into a whole new side for that. My love for the characters is what amazes me the most, as that's the strongest suit for this anime. I enjoyed most of the animes, but some scenes (especially the CGI and pointless drama scenes can be taken out).


Overall:

My overall opinion of this anime is that it's an anime that is fun, which portays happy looking girls having a fun time at what they're doing. It's essentially not ideal for everyone as some don't like female ONLY animes or pop music animes but you need to take into consideration that the character development for this anime is a job well done. 


In my opinion, the things that this anime should focus on improving is the CGI scenes because they just simply look disgusting and unprofessional and also fix up the story so it flows smoothly without these random events occurring. Nevertheless, it's a happy anime to watch.


Story - 8

Art - 7

Sound - 7

Character - 8

Enjoyment - 7

Overall - 7.4


TL;DR - Watch this anime if you're into pop music and girls having fun while doing girly things (because you seriously won't expect a male character).

So, love live! The massive mutlimedia project that overtook japan for several years (still a bit at this date). This is this project's anime. I alsoplay the game and listen to all of the love live! songs and go to live screenings.  (warining : minor spoilers)


To start out, I have to say this anime is very very uplifting, so uplifting that the story is cheesy. Ever wondered how life would be if everything turned out the best possible way every situation? That pretty much explains this anime. That is also the goal of this anime, making everything surreal and amazing, but that's also the charm and what makes this anime special. Is it sooo uplifting, it actually made me so joyful the time I watched it. Although, the plot is pretty predictable, its very fun to watch, 8/10


For the art itself, I am in love, although the 3d cgi in the songs isn't the best, the rest, from akihabara, to the characters (so damn cute), to the school is very pretty, and suits my personnal taste very well, 9/10.


For the sound, the seiyuus (voice actresseses) made a very excellent job, and I like each and every one of them. The music was to die for (if you like this kind of music, idol stuff) and the soundtrack matched the anime and its moments. 10/10.


Ah, the characters, all of them get developped and are so well thought. They all stand out and complement each other so well, its almost too perfect. I thank this project for making me discover Minami Kotori, my love, my life, my soul (when the first episode came out). Although, to seriously judge, all of the character in this series get a bit of developpement, and are pretty developped, I have nothing to say and like them all.  10/10


If you are a regular anime viewer and want something very cheerful, musical, a bit touchy, funny and with good music and art, you should give it a go. Please take note it is a slice of life. So overall, kotori is in it, so my review is a bit biaised, but, the anime itself made me fall in idol hell and its songs = no regrets. Also, I think the anime itself isn't the best thing from this project, the best thing about this project in my opinion are the characters and the music.
